docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Deaths of Unwanted Babies Prompt Calls to Ease Laws'' (front page, March 6), you report that ''some advocates for children say efforts should be focused on providing options to women when they are pregnant.'' While we agree that this is mandatory, including counseling on prenatal care, adoption and abortion, we know that measures must be taken well before the woman becomes pregnant.
docs.abstract: Letter from Joan Malin of Planned Parenthood of New York City comments on March 6 article on providing options to women considering abandoning their newborns; says sex education curriculum might reduce number of unwanted pregnancies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: State Assemblywoman Audrey 0. Hochberg, 66, Democrat of Scarsdale, has announced that she will not seek re-election in November. She was first elected to the Assembly in 1992 from the 88th Assembly District. Before that, from 1972 through 1991, she served as a county legislator. Mrs. Hochberg is the chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Adult Education and the Commission on Solid Waste Management.
docs.abstract: New York State Assemblywoman Audrey O Hochberg, Democrat of Scarsdale, announces retirement (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A young Moroccan woman, now 21 and living in Queens, won asylum in the United States in August after fleeing North Africa and her father, a fundamentalist Muslim who beat her, locked her in her room and denied her an education. The case continues to frustrate lawyers for immigrant women fleeing abuse, even though it was a victory on the surface. In granting her asylum, the United States Board of Immigration Appeals defined her plight as religious persecution rather than domestic abuse. That means the ruling offered no greater hope for women seeking asylum based on abuse at the hands of fathers and brothers, husbands and boyfriends.

headline.main: Agency Struggles With Asylum Policy in Gender Abuse Cases

docs.abstract: US Immigration and Naturalization Service struggles to reckon with one of thorniest asylum issues: how to deal consistently and fairly with thousands of women who seek asylum for what is termed gender abuse; Bo Cooper, agency general counsel, says agency is trying to figure out how international definition of a refugee, written half century ago, should be applied to novel kinds of cases such as domestic violence, where women seek asylum based on abuse at hands of fathers and brothers, husbands and boyfriends (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two and a half years ago, Liz Lange had hardly any experience in the clothing design business; all she knew she had learned during a two-year stint assisting a young dress designer. But in 1997 she noticed a market she felt had not been addressed. She calls it ''normal-looking clothes that happen to be maternity.'' So Ms. Lange designed a maternity line with eight basic samples and worked by appointment out of an office building. Over the next year and a half, she expanded her line and opened a 600-square-foot second-floor store at 1020 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street). On March 1, she relocated to a 3,000-square-foot store at 958 Madison Avenue (75th Street).

headline.main: A Baby Business Is Growing Quickly

docs.abstract: Liz Lange moves her maternity clothing store to Madison Avenue at 75th Street (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just three days after the Super Tuesday presidential primary, Hillary Rodham Clinton sought today to link Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her opponent in the race for United States Senate, with the Republican Party's all-but-nominated presidential candidate, Gov. George W. Bush. It is part of a strategy, Mrs. Clinton's aides say, to capitalize on both the strength that Vice President Al Gore, the presumed Democratic candidate, has shown in polls among New York voters and what the Clinton campaign sees as the unpopularity in New York of some of Governor Bush's positions.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Tries to Link Giuliani's Policies to Bush's

docs.abstract: Hillary Clinton, campaigning for Senate in New York with Al Gore, links Rudolph Giuliani, her opponent, with Republican party's likely presidential nominee, George W Bush; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Desperate parents who do not want their newborn babies would be able to abandon them at hospitals or other safe places without fear of criminal prosecution, under legislation endorsed today by the Republican leaders of the State Senate. The legislators said the proposal was intended to address the growing problem of infants who are left to die every year in Dumpsters, bathrooms and other dangerous hiding places. Under state law, a mother who leaves a baby at a hospital without identifying herself or taking other legal steps for adoption faces arrest for child abandonment, a felony with a maximum penalty of 16 months to 4 years in prison.
docs.abstract: Desperate parents who do not want their newborn babies will be able to abandon them at hospitals or other safe places without fear of criminal prosecution, under legislation endorsed by Republican leaders of State Senate; Sen Nancy Larraine Hoffmann is bill's main sponsor; lawmakers say change in law would essentially legalize practice that has been in place for years in Syracuse and western parts of state (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Next Best Thing Madonna, Rupert Everett, Benjamin Bratt, Malcolm Stumpf, Michael Vartan Directed by John Schlesinger PG-13 107 minutes Think ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' but with major twists in relationships and living arrangements. When Abbie (Madonna), a yoga instructor, is dumped by her boyfriend (Mr. Vartan), she clings to her best friend, Robert (Mr. Everett), who is gay. After getting drunk on the Fourth of July, they make love and voila: a pregnancy that grows markedly by the scene until we have little Sam (Malcolm Stumpf). Assured that he is the father, Robert takes his parenting duties to heart and the three make up a comfy household until six years later, when different sexual orientations finally exert their pull. Abbie becomes involved with Ben (Mr. Bratt), a generic investment banker who's on the banal side but not too bad a person. Robert is the problem, turning aggressively possessive of Sam and threatened by what increasingly becomes a drift toward a new family alignment.

headline.main: Family Values: Mom and Dad Are Battling Over the Boy

docs.abstract: Peter M Nichols Taking the Children reviews of films The Next Best Thing, Hanging Up and Boiler Room; photo (S)
